body:
> If the device happens to be behind v4 NAT but anyway has native v6 and announces to the discovery server over v6 we might not get the external v4 address - but the v6 one should work as well.

A v6 address will not help a device that can only connect to the internet over v4, which is sadly still quite common, so not having the external v4 address is a big problem.

Good point, so we will need to ensure announcements can happen over v4. Requiring v6 announcements and lookups to happen over v6 currently filters out the cases where v6 is configured but blackholed / not working. I don't think this is a case that specifically needs handling. So we could just make sure that announcements happen over v4 when possible, falling back to v6 for v6-only hosts.

A tangential but slightly related thought: currently devices continue to poll the discovery servers for devices to which they are already connected, to see if a better protocol becomes available. If devices gain the ability to announce their alternative addresses to each other, then they no longer need to poll the discovery servers for a device they're connected to, which should reduce the load a bit.

For those keeping note, it looks like DigitalOcean Spaces is probably not the solution here. My quick PoC deployment is currently being met with

```
handleAnnounce: 503 Slow Down
POST /v2/ completed in 25.108074468s (slow request)
```

that is, it's taking 25 seconds to tell me that we've exceeded a rate limit. For every request. There are no documented rate limits that I can found. I've opened a support ticket, but I wouldn't be surprised if the response is that our use case is not the one they envision or something along those lines...

Thinking further, you could allow all devices in a network to share discovered addresses, meaning that only one device in a given network needs to be talking to the discovery servers.

One way to do this would be to allow devices to query each other for addresses, and do this in preference to contacting the global discovery servers. However, a device will leak information to its peers on what other devices it is interested in, which I supposed you could mitigate by instead querying for hash(device id + timestamp). Also if you have A <--> B <--> C, where A and C know about a fourth device D (but B doesn't), A and C can't share information on D's address.

Another way is, whenever a device retrieves an address from the global discovery servers (or announces its own address to the global discovery servers), it announces it to all of its peers, as a [hash(device id + timestamp), encrypt(address, device id)] tuple. Devices then relay this to their peers, being careful to avoid cycles. If a device sees an entry for a device it is interested in, it resets its timeout for polling the global discovery servers, and adds a minute or so of extra time (to avoid all devices in a network racing and hitting the global discovery servers simultaneously after the timeout).

Note of course that this all falls down if you don't trust your peers to give you correct information.

(All of this is orthogonal to the work around K/V stores, of course, but potentially still relevant to making global discovery more scalable, by reducing load on it).

It's relevant and we should do it, yet orthogonal to the issue of still scaling the remaining global discovery. For what it's worth I've done a decent amount of actual engineering on this today, experimenting on discovery-v[46]-4, and noticed a few things. - I've tweaked the Retry-After and Reannounce-After headers so that devices reannounce after one hour (unless something changes), and hold off on asking for a device for five minutes when it gets a 404 response. This reduces the amount of requests somewhat. - DigitalOcean Spaces are limited to 200 requests/s which is nowhere near the capacity we need, regardless of whether we do the requests ourselves or plan to let the clients look things up there directly. - etcd seems like a nice distributed KV store so I wrote up support for that and deployed in on a triple of 2GB/2CPU boxes on DO. Unfortunately it didn't really scale with our use case and there aren't any relevant tunables: - Technologically, Amazon DynamoDB is also decent fit for a backend KV-store and we wouldn't need to worry about how it scales. I wrote up support for that and deployed a triple of t2.medium machines as frontends. Those were able to handle the load nicely, to begin with, and the DB scales up to the required read/write performance. Unfortunately the required read/write performance comes at a $150/month level, the three t2.medium instances aren't exactly free, and after a while they got throttled down to 20% of their initial CPU rate by Amazon. I guess I was in some sort of burst mode just after deployment. - Rethinking this I realized that the data isn't really valuable enough to keep in a separate KV store and we should just try the simplest thing possible. To this end I rewrote the discosrv backend to just be a RAM-backed map and added replication - just duplicating updates to a preconfigured set of peers so we can load balance. The latter is now deployed on DO again, on a pair of high-cpu boxes (again, expensive). They are humming along very nicely though so we will be able to scale them down a bit. I also added some relevant metrics. One thing is that we get about 150 announcements/s, and these are expensive as they check the client certificate and stuff. Out of these, about 100 are re-announces where just the KCP address has changed, from 0.14.40 boxes. Since these addresses change every 24 seconds, 100/(1/24) corresponds to 2400 devices which is about how many 0.14.40 boxes are still out there according to data.s.n. I think one of the major connectivity issues in 0.14.40 that was still there in 0.14.41 was just that the global disco servers were totally DoSed... When this abates we should be able to turn down the boxes to a cheaper config, and then just add smaller boxes or upgrade them one by one as load increases over time. I've given up on being able to offload the TLS termination to someone else.

Wasn't tls offload handled by nginx?

Perhaps aws elb or cloudflare supports that these days and is able to provide the certificate.

Yeah, handled by nginx today. I haven't checked out the details on those TLS LB things, it's possible they could support it. Some metrics on the new cluster for the curious: https://monitor.syncthing.net/ One thing I will still want to do is separate lookup from announce client side. Syncthing will do two announces as today, to discovery-v4.s.n and discovery-v6.s.n, but there is no point in doing separate lookups. Instead the backend will merge and all lookups can go to discovery.s.n (dual stack). This removes the 20% extra that is IPv6 only lookups today, a fraction that will only increase. Also curious effect - any few second outage is like ringing a bell with a global give five minute oscillation for several hours afterwards... Because the retries become synchronized.

The ringing effect could probably be easily mitigated long-term on the by adding a small amount of jitter (+- 1-2s maybe?) to the first couple of queries after a failure to connect.  The jitter doesn't even have to be particularly nondeterministic for that matter if it's implemented server-side by adjusting the value sent in the Retry-After header (in that case, you could just adjust by the value of a counter that increments per-request modulo 5 minus 2 and get reasonable smoothing after a few requests).

Yep, I've added some randomization now, even though this is more of a curiosity than an actual problem.

System is currently running on a pair of Scaleway "C2S" servers, four core Atom C2550s. These are about equivalent to the DigitalOcean "high CPU" dual Xeons but with twice the memory and at a third of  the cost. On the other hand Scaleway has technical issues that I've discovered in the two days of testing, takes days to respond to support requests (no response yet), and had a two minute network blip on one of the servers this morning. So I guess we get what we pay for, but it seems adequate anyway for the purpose.

While it may not be a problem right now, It could be in the future, so having the randomization is still good.

Also, as far as the servers, you might consider looking at [Vultr](https://www.vultr.com/).  Their instances cost about half of what Digitalocean charges for equivalent hardware with bigger disks but a slightly lower bandwidth allowance (though it's not a hard cap for the bandwidth, just pro-rated above the allowance per-month), and they've got pretty good support from what I hear (I've never had to submit a ticket myself, so i don't know how good it is myself, but the couple of friends who pointed me at them had positively glowing reviews of their customer support team).

DigitalOcean [announced a major price drop across their Droplet product line](https://blog.digitalocean.com/new-droplet-plans/) last week. The 2GB/2CPU box @calmh referenced is available for $15/mo instead of $20/mo previously. A quick resize of the current servers will utilize DO's new price tiers.
Yes, I've tweaked all our DO instances accordingly
